ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Electro-optic switch based on near-field-coupled quantum dots

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Laboratory of Photonics and Microwave Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The propagation of exciton polaritons in near-field-coupled quantum-dot (QD) chains is modeled by a density-matrix formalism. It is shown that at least for low-temperature operation it is possible using electronically controlled switching by the quantum-confined Stark effect in such QD chains to rival and outperform room-temperature CMOS electronics in footprint and switch energy, though not in speed.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: There seems to be scant possibilities to continue the exponential development in integration density for photonics into true nanophotonics [1] since much of this development to ever smaller structures, one condition for integratability and low power dissipation, an increasingly important metric, has been based on plasmonics. Here, however, the losses give an unforgiving barrier to many ICT applications (though not hindering a wealth of other applications such as for sensors) and to more complex integration. The authors have researched the limits and tradeoffs involved here [1, 2], and also shown that one can in principle compensate losses with gain in resonantly operated plasmonics devices (i.e. where the confinement is highest) [3], with, e.g. quantum-dot (QD) based amplification in composite particle arrays, but power dissipation and (in ICT systems) signal-to-noise ratio degradation are rather forbidding [4]. And indeed, development in shrinking dimensions for e.g. filters and modulators have slowed down. Power dissipation or Joule heating in the context of nanophotonics is an important parameter, both from more fundamental aspects and for applications, where it could be a limiting factor, as it indeed is for today’s electronics ICs. Another drawback of plasmonics is the difficulty to change material characteristics, e.g. by changing the plasma frequency except in doped semiconductors where this is possible by varying charge carrier concentration, albeit in the THz plasmonics regime.

Thus, it is interesting to explore an alternate route, that of Förster resonant energy transfer (FRET), i.e. transfer of exciton polaritons, in either near-field-coupled quantum dots (QDs) or molecular systems for creating waveguides and electronically controlled photonics modulators and switches. These FRET-coupled nanoarrays could open a possibility to continue the exponential development described in [1], since in comparison to near-field-coupled plasmonic arrays they offer much less power dissipation, smaller size as well as electronic controllability. The losses incurred here are essentially spontaneous emission (~10 ns time constant) and material and excitation-dependent nonradiative emission, e.g. Auger recombination. Nonradiative losses due to material imperfections can be brought down to negligible levels compared to the spontaneous emission in core–shell QDs, as evidenced by a near unity quantum yield [5]. Thus the decay rates of the FRET-coupled QD arrays are orders of magnitude lower than the ~10 fs decay of plasmon polaritons. The drawbacks are a more complex technology and lower signal power in the arrays.

The FRET technique has been readily available in biology at least since the 1950s to determine proximity or shape changes of molecules [6]. More recently, it has been applied to semiconductor QDs to demonstrate energy transfer in thin QD array layers [7–11], and in organic systems FRET has been demonstrated in DNA-based linear arrays of organic chromophores (dyes) [12]. As the name suggests, FRET depends on energy levels in the donor and acceptor particle to be resonant, and it is thus interesting to examine switching as a result of changing this resonance. Particularly QDs have substantial Stark shifts [13]. This principle has been demonstrated in a mix of semiconductor QDs and dye particles, where the QDs have a substantially larger Stark shift than the dye particles [14]. The purpose of this paper is to evaluate pulse propagation of exciton polaritons on linear arrays and assessing modulation in a proposed modulator structure. Finally, due to the low excitation energy in signal propagation, different ways of increasing total transmitted energy, by 2 or 3D “bands”, will be analyzed, with the aim of achieving high enough signal-to-noise (fundamentally quantum noise) ratio. Our analysis is carried out at low temperature (0 K) neglecting dephasing, as well as for 77 K; room-temperature operation is of course highly desirable. Inhomogeneous broadening for the QDs is not taken into account in this paper, since it is not considered a fundamental boundary condition; when present it certainly has a noticeable influence.

The application scope is mainly ICT (telecom and photonics interconnects). The requirements here could for a single device roughly be summarized as
Longitudinal size < or ≪1,000 nm
Transverse size < or ≪104 nm2 (much below the diffraction limit)
Joule dissipation <1 fJ/time slot
Insertion loss <1 dB
Bandwidth > or ≫10 GHz
Transmitted signal power: 100–1,000 photons/time slot
The possibilities to use DNA technology to position the individual nanoparticles [15] constitute an interesting bridge to bio applications.

Section1.Heading: Theory of exciton polariton transfer in QD arrays
Section1.Para:
We consider a chain of colloidal InAs/GaAs core–shell quantum dots embedded in an organic host as shown in Fig. 1. For the sake of example the host material may be a polymer, or organic ligand molecules, which can be used to control the distance between the QDs, e.g. [15]. Such organic hosts have a considerably higher bandgap than the semiconductor QD so that we may neglect the Dexter transfer process, i.e. carrier tunneling, and focus on FRET, i.e. the transfer of exciton polaritons by near-field coupling.

Section1.Heading: Pulse propagation on a QD array
Section1.Para: Excitation transfer in terms of near-field-coupled (Förster) transfer of exciton polaritons has been demonstrated in both organic (dye particles) [12] and non-organic (QDs) systems [7–11]. In this paper, we do not treat the input and output coupling to the array. The coherent excitation is a special condition that is assumed in the calculations. Throughout the paper we neglect inhomogeneous broadening. Below, we treat several cases of excitation propagation on the QD array assuming different excitation conditions and temperature-dependent dephasing.

First, we examine the excitation evolution on the QD chain when QD 1 is excited with one exciton at t = 0. Figure 2 shows the results for both transverse, ρ 1z,1z(t = 0) = 1, and longitudinal excitation, ρ 1x,1x(t = 0) = 1. As can be seen, a propagating pulse develops with a fairly rapid pulse disintegration and a tail is developing, similar to the results of [17]. In Fig. 2b a reflection is seen at the end of the QD array with N = 30 QDs.

Section1.Heading: Optical modulation
Section1.Para: Having analyzed in some detail the issue of exciton polariton propagation along a QD array, we now turn to the use of such array waveguides for different device structures. Important photonics devices are modulators, switches (i.e. devices where a spatial input can be directed to several outputs) and wavelength selective devices. Here we will concentrate on the modulators. We will study structures where only a few QDs are involved in the modulation process, implementing a truly nanophotonics structure. We will investigate modulator structure and operation, switch energy, and speed. A peculiar feature of these modulators is, as we will see, that the switch energy will be dependent on transmitted energy, in stark contrast to conventional external modulators.

Section2.Heading: Modulator structure
Section2.Para:
Figure 4 shows one possible structure for controlling propagation of exciton polaritons on the QD array: a top contact electrode is arranged above the QD array, which in turn is positioned above a conducting substrate, e.g. a doped semiconductor layer. The preferred method of operation for modulation is to utilize the quantum confined Stark effect. An applied voltage will then give rise to an energy shift of the QDs in the vicinity of the top contact that will control the resonance condition between these QDs. To some extent also the electron–hole wavefunction overlap is reduced by the applied electric field. Both effects affect the Förster coupling between the QDs and hence the transmission on the QD array. The QD in the position under the top contact will be subjected to the highest applied field and we call this the control QD, though due to the small 10 nm spacing of the QDs the QDs adjacent to the top contact will also be affected by the field. An elongated QD (nanorod) may be used as the control QD, Fig. 4, to enhance both the energy shift and the reduced wavefunction overlap of this QD. Modulation results both with a nanorod and with a regular spherical QD, respectively, acting as the control QD, are examined.
Fig. 4
Schematic figure of the analyzed modulator structure comprising InAs/GaAs core–shell QDs in an organic host material and an electrode arrangement for controlling exciton–polariton propagation along the QD array. The electrode separation of the top contact and conducting substrate is 20 nm

Section2.Heading: Stark shifting of the QD transition energies
Section2.Para:
The distribution of the modulating RF electric field due to an applied voltage to the top electrode is obtained in a 3D calculation in COMSOL. Due to dual symmetries of the modulator structure, along the x and y axes, it is sufficient to obtain the solution for a quarter of the structure, and the result is shown in Fig. 5 for the applied voltage V a = 0.2 V. The E-field is lower in the QDs than in the organic host as seen in Fig. 5a, due to depolarization resulting from the higher permittivities of the semiconductor materials. The RF permittivities used are ε h = 2.6 in the organic host, ε InAs = 15.15 in the QD cores and ε GaAs = 12.9 in the QD shells. The E-field in the QDs is more readily seen in Fig. 5b, c in a plane and a line, respectively, cutting through the QD centers. Figure 5c also shows the two cases of a nanorod or a spherical QD acting as the control QD, with a higher modulating E-field resulting for the nanorod. The QD InAs core radius is 3.2 nm [16], while the nanorod InAs core length and diameter is taken to be 10 and 2.5 nm, respectively. A 1 nm GaAs shell is assumed for both particles.
Fig. 5
Modulating RF-signal E-field strengths at 0.2 V applied voltage, a side view, and b top view intersecting the QD plane, respectively, for the case of a nanorod as the control QD, c the same in a line through the QD centers for the cases of a nanorod (blue line) or a spherical QD (green line) as the control QD. The QD numbers 20–25 are indicated. Due to symmetry the applied fields for QDs 19↓15 are the same as for 21↑25

The Stark shift of colloidal QDs has been examined in some detail in the literature, e.g. [13]. However, results for InAs QDs as we have elected to use are scarce. We, therefore, use a 1D QW model to estimate the Stark shift in the shape of a polarizability and the effect of the E-field on the electron–hole wavefunction overlap. To this end, for the spherical QD, we assume an effective 1D well width L eff as the side of a cube with the same volume as the QD, i.e. L eff = (4π/3)1/3 R QD = 5.2 nm. For the nanorod with an InAs core length of 10 nm we use L eff = 9 nm. The results of both the Stark shift and the electron–hole overlap integral can be very well fitted to quadratic relations vs. the electric field in the InAs well layer with the quadratic coefficents p nr = 0.26 meV/(V/μm)2, p s = 0.047 meV/(V/μm)2, q nr = 1.8 × 10−3 (V/μm)−2, and q s = 1.4 × 10−4 (V/μm)−2.

The transmittance of the two studied modulator structures, comprising a nanorod or a spherical QD as the control QD, is shown in Fig. 7a, b, respectively, for transverse and longitudinal waves at T = 0 and 77 K. We see that when using the nanorod a voltage swing of only ≈0.1 V is sufficient for a 10-dB extinction ratio at T = 0 K, increasing to ≈0.2 V at T = 77 K. And that simply using a spherical QD identical to the other QDs in the waveguide, Fig. 7b, is surprisingly efficient, despite the nearly six times smaller Stark shift compared to the nanorod, with a required voltage swing of ≈0.3 V for around 10 dB extinction ratio at T = 77 K. It thus appears that the several smaller relative Stark shifts between the QDs adjacent to the top contact, see Fig. 5a, are fully sufficient for efficient operation of the modulator. Hence the extra complexity added by having to align the nanorod and the top contact at the same lateral position is not a requirement although it does reduce the voltage somewhat.

Figure 8 shows propagationwise two examples of the results in Fig. 7, viz. propagation of longitudinal Gaussian pulses at T = 0 K, using a nanorod or a spherical QD as the control QD, when the transmittance has been reduced by 10 dB by the applied voltage V a. It is evident that a significant part of the incoming wave can be captured by the lower QD transition energies in the vicinity of the contact. This capture probability is shown in Fig. 7c, d. There is also a substantial reflection, which per se is not so desirable in modulators. Energy capture is a property not present in “conventional” modulators, such as those based on the electrooptic effect or quantum-confined Stark effect. The decay of the captured excitation is negligible on the studied time-scale as seen in Fig 8. At T = 77 K there is a noticeable decay of captured longitudinal waves (but not of transverse ones) with a 1/e decay time of about 30 and 40 ps in the nanorod and spherical QD modulator structures, respectively. Section2.Heading: Switch energy
Section2.Para:
Turning to the issue of switch energy: if each longitudinal strand of QDs is assumed to carry one exciton in this case at 0.8 eV, per time slot, it would not be sufficient for ICT applications, where for shot noise limited detection 21 photons is required in a logical “1” bit for 10−9 bit error rate. One remedy is to have two- or three-dimensional arrays extending vertically and into the plane of the paper in Fig. 4, with the number of strands being N V and N O, respectively. In this case, employing a very simple model, capacitance C would be inversely proportional to N V and proportional to N O. However, the voltage Va applied to the contact of Fig. 4 would be proportional to N V. The switch energy E SW [20] is given by 11

Section1.Heading: Summary and conclusions
Section1.Para: Above we attempted to describe an alternative to the hitherto rather prevalent plasmonics for nanophotonics, an alternative that would be “even more nanophotonics” and at the same time giving low power dissipation avoiding localized heating, as in plasmonics. The theoretical understanding of the waveguides and corresponding devices need to be further developed, experimental results have typically been devoted merely to the transmittance.

Issues are possibilities for room temperature operation, required signal power, excitation, inhomogeneous broadening, incoupling and outcoupling to name some. And the technological challenges in the fabrication and testing of these device structures are considerable. However, the concept is theoretically close to or actually meeting the tentative performance requirements mentioned in the introduction, Sec. 1.

Above, we have assumed that a coherent excitation and propagation is feasible. But even a totally noncoherent propagation due to hopping could be used as long as unidirectional propagation takes place. Grading of the transition energies is one way that has been demonstrated [9, 12], but is costly in dissipated energy. Using electrical “herding” signals or varying interparticle distances may be other ways.

The available operation speed of the modulator is limited by several factors: The RC time constant, as in a conventional modulator, and a minimum pulse length (here 6 ps) that allows propagation with only minor pulse broadening. The RC limited frequency is extremely high (>THz) due to the low capacitance (2 aF in the example above). The minimum pulse length can be tailored to some extent by choice of QD and coupling strength; in the example above it would limit speed to about 50 GHz, sufficient for many applications.

It is interesting to compare the switch energy derived above to demonstrated photonic switches, e.g. in our recent review of low-power switches [20]. A very low switching energy of 7 fJ/bit was demonstrated in a silicon depletion-mode ring modulator, not counting the thermal tuning power [21]. For a III–V traveling-wave electroabsorption modulator a switching energy of 300 fJ/bit has been demonstrated [22], while compact Si Mach–Zehnder modulators typically have switching energies of several pJ/bit [23]. Compared to the ring modulator [21] the 8 aJ switching energy, assuming 100 excitons per time slot, for the modulator simulated in this paper is three orders of magnitude smaller, albeit at a lower temperature T = 77 K. As for the footprint of the present device it is on the order of 30 × 30 (50 × 50) nm2, when a nanorod (spherical QD) is used as the control QD, to avoid interference of adjacent devices. The former footprint is six orders of magnitude smaller than that of the ring modulator.

A further interesting issue is to compare to CMOS electronics: Intel state-of-the-art 22 nm feature size gives sub-ps gate delay time and ~20 aJ dissipated switch energy. Thus the QD array device is comparable in footprint and switch energy (for 100 photons per time slot), but not in speed for single arrays due to insufficient signal-to-noise ratio, even though the excitation transfer can be on the order of ps. The device described here seems to be one of the few or the only electrooptic modulator/switch showing such “electronics-like” performance. Again, it should be noted that CMOS operation is at room temperature, whereas our results pertain to 77 K.
